publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 80.29

seg.seg: .... I (saw) suffering. For me nowhere the kinsmen (were) shelter (and refuge)
.... these are sitting indifferently(?). Whoever among the kinsmen are now worried
[65d] Whoever [are] here wealthy rich creatures, (they) [are] there(by)
... such ones love possession. [66d] And therefore even more carefully
... No-one praises himself before the others, then. [67d] Let alone ....
Niemand eben preist sich selbst vor den anderen.
Nobody, then, praises himself in front of others.
... (When) there is (not) anything else to be sold by me, [then] I sell myself
(Wenn) von mir jetzt (nichts) anderes zu verkaufen ist, [so] verkaufe ich mich selbst ...
(If) [there] is (nothing) else to be sold by me, I [will] sell myself ...
... Whatever this one’s meditation or whatever [this one’s] insight [may be], the kleśas (will destroy for him)
... For however long, however, the virtues increase in this one’s mind, so long also all
.... Not even in the least did the Omniscient praise the births, let alone at length such birth
.... with [the] exception (of all hell-places) I have been born in every one, dies in every one
.... if anything had been here. So often [have] I [been] born
.... through the births. With being born and dying he will be satiated.
.... the virtues altogether. And everyone, who has gathered all merits
.... [75d] If a monk behaves according to these twelve ways
.... (he reaches the Nirvāṇa-(?))place. [76d] In Dharmasoma’s Udānālaṅkāra
.... if therefore he thinks each good deed to be the best,

p.note: On the verso side this leaf fragment contains the beginning of a colophon in b7; before this, it contains strophes 64-76 in a 4x11-syllable-metre (rhythm = 6/5 or 5/6). The metre in b8 cannot be determined with any certainty. There is no hint that would allow an allocation to any specific varga, and the translation must be regarded as an attempt only.
Torn-off right side, about 1/3 of a leaf.
The virāma is missing on the m of ṣṣim.
According to 92 fn. 6 the reading mläṅkṣalle should be corrected to pläṅkṣalle in the transcription.

list.item: a1 /// ṣṣi_m _l_aklenta : mā ñi kca ṣañä\ śāmna waste a2 /// sr[e]ppe cai ṣameṃ : k_use ṣañä\ śāmnane ñke prā a3 /// – 5 k_use tne waipeccecci śateñ onolmi : tu a4 /// m(·) ce_u lareṃ waipecce 60-6 tusa ṣp olypw= ānaiśai a5 /// – m[ā] su nt= ālye_k_aśco ṣañ-añ_mä\ _p_allā_t_a_r 60-7 k_uce ṣ no a6 /// ks= alle_k\ ñke ñi _m_l_aṅkṣalle ne_s_aṃ : ṣañ-añ_mä\ _p_l_aṅsema_r\ a7 /// – k_use cwi ompalśkoññe k_use wa_t\ aiśamñe : kleśanma na a8 /// : kos no cwi palskone tsmān_t_a_r\ krentauna : to_t\ _ṣ_p_a po b1 /// – – tka ra cmela mā poyśi palāte : k_uce ṣ no emparkre ce_u cme b2 /// nta _pas_t\ śeśśamormeṃ : pone ñi_ś\ temtsamai pone srukā b3 /// – [·au]pāntsa tu ksa kr_ui nesalle ṣai tne : to_t\ ñi_ś\ tetemu b4 /// c[m]elasa : cmelñe srūkalñesa tākaṃ sosoyu : _p_a b5 /// ysomo krentauna : po ṣ po yärponta kakraupau b6 /// _ṣ_ṣ_aṃ 70-5 ceṃ śakwi klautkeṃtsa spārtaṃ ṣamā b7 /// īke 70-6 || dharmaso_m_aññe udā b8 /// [sa] śpalmeṃ plāskaṃ ṣeme ṣṣeme _k_artsauñe

Transliteration

a1. The virāma is missing on the m of ṣṣim.

a6. According to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 92 fn. 6 the reading mläṅkṣalle should be corrected to pläṅkṣalle in the transcription.

Transcription

b6. Emendation according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 92 fn. 8.

b6. Emendation according to [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 93 fn. 1.

General remarks

On the verso side this leaf fragment contains the beginning of a colophon in b7; before this, it contains strophes 64-76 in a 4x11-syllable-metre (rhythm = 6/5 or 5/6). The metre in b8 cannot be determined with any certainty. There is no hint that would allow an allocation to any specific varga, and the translation must be regarded as an attempt only.

a1 .... I (saw) suffering. For me nowhere the kinsmen (were) shelter (and refuge) a2 .... these are sitting indifferently(?). Whoever among the kinsmen are now worried a3 [65d] Whoever [are] here wealthy rich creatures, (they) [are] there(by) a4 ... such ones love possession. [66d] And therefore even more carefully a5 ... No-one praises himself before the others, then. [67d] Let alone .... a6 ... (When) there is (not) anything else to be sold by me, [then] I sell myself a7 ... Whatever this one’s meditation or whatever [this one’s] insight [may be], the kleśas (will destroy for him) a8 ... For however long, however, the virtues increase in this one’s mind, so long also all b1 .... Not even in the least did the Omniscient praise the births, let alone at length such birth b2 .... with [the] exception (of all hell-places) I have been born in every one, dies in every one b3 .... if anything had been here. So often [have] I [been] born b4 .... through the births. With being born and dying he will be satiated. b5 .... the virtues altogether. And everyone, who has gathered all merits b6 .... [75d] If a monk behaves according to these twelve ways b7 .... (he reaches the Nirvāṇa-(?))place. [76d] In Dharmasoma’s Udānālaṅkāra b8 .... if therefore he thinks each good deed to be the best,

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-1/2
Tamai-C14–
